Kenneth Stanley wrote:

>The following position statement will be appearing in a worskhop at 
>GECCO and may be of interest to people in this group interested in 
>indirect encoding:
>
>"Exploiting Morphological Conventions for Genetic Reuse"
>
>http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/keyword?stanley:gecco04ws
>
>Joe Reisinger is also a coauthor.
>
>ken
>  
>

Food for thought. I experimented with a tree based genome structure last 
year and was intending to take a fresh look at that work once I had a 
working NEAT implementation. The way my code is organized I should be 
able to switch one genome represenation for another with relative ease. 
I might still do this but I can see that the tree structure which allows 
copying of sub-branches and also nodes that refer to sub-branches is a 
divide-and-conquer approach - it doesn't fully allow for specialization 
of already evolved structures although I did allow for extra nodes on 
the tree after a reference-node. This allowed for expressing a sub-part 
of the tree genome in the phenotype and then attaching further neurons 
and connections to it, but it didnt allow for overriding existing 
structure, e.g. re-use of a structure but with some different 
connections weights. Yeh, so from this I would draw a distinction 
between specialization by extension and specialization by modification.

I still see that sort of approach as being brittle when compared to a 
genome representation that specifies rules for growing structures rather 
than encoding the structures directly. I suppose it's a half-way-house 
of sorts.

Colin.
